category.catDesc: The name used by Syriaca.org for document titles, citation, and disambiguation. These names have been created according to the Syriac.org guidelines for headwords: http://syriaca.org/documentation/headwords.html.
An anglicized version of a name, included to facilitate searching.
Indicates the content is canonical, i.e., widely agreed upon. Abbreviations of work titles are primarily in view.

bibl.title: Mark (Peshitta version)
ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܟܪܘܙܘܬܐ ܕܡܪܩܘܣ
ܣܦܪܐ ܕܡܪܩܘܣ
Mark
Mark
ܐܶܘܰܓܶܠܺܝܳܘܢ ܩܰܕܺܝܫܳܐ ܣܒܰܪܬܳܐ ܕܡܰܪܩܳܘܣ ܡܣܰܒܪܳܢܳܐ
ܫܠܡܬܐ ܟܪܘܙܘܬܐ ܕܡܪܩܘܣ ܕܡܠܠ ܪܗܘܡܐܝܬ ܒܪܗܘܡܐ
S. Mark
The Gospel of S. Mark, according to the Peshitta version
ܫܠܡ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܟܪܘܙܘܬܐ ܕܡܪܩܘܣ ܕܡܠܠ ܪܗܘܡܐܝܬ ܒܪܗܘܡܐ.
S. Mark, according to the Peshitta version
ܫܠܡ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܟܪܘܙܘܬܐ ܕܡܪܩܘܣ. ܕܡܠ̣ܠ ܪܗܘܡܐܝܬ ܒܪܗܘܡܐ ܡܕܝܢܬܐ. ܘܗ̣ܘ ܝܬ݂ܒ ܐܦܣܩܘܦܐ ܩܕܡܝܐ ܒܐܠܟܣܢܕܪܝܐ ܪܒܬܐ.
Mark, according to the Peshitta version
The Gospel of Mark according to the Peshitta version
The Gospel of Mark
bibl.note:
The Gospel of Mark (Peshitta version)
is a designation for a group of texts translating the Greek Gospel of Mark, beginning in the early 5th century and appearing in manuscripts as early as the 5th or 6th century. It bears similarities to previous Syriac translations, the Diatessaron and Mark (Old Syriac) , but its exact relationship to these versions is still a matter of debate, as is the uniformity of the text itself. It generally reflects the Greek more closely than Mark (Old Syriac)
does.
ܪܫܐ ܕܿܐܘܢܓܿܠܝܘܢ ܕܿܝܫܘܼܥ ܡܫܝܚܐ܃ ܒܿܪܗ ܕܿܐܠܗܐ ܀܀
